subject: Re: The goals of CMM (Re: [junit] wanted Junit professionals urgently)
msgSnippet: ... On the contrary: it admits the single most important quantitative analysis. How many dollars are my clients willing to pay me to continue building their
messageBody:
Michael Holly wrote:

> Your definiton of Better Software lacks any sort of standards to make a
> quantitative analysis.

On the contrary: it admits the single most important quantitative analysis.

How many dollars are my clients willing to pay
me to continue building their software?

> How fast? How much value? What is business value? Unless your definition
> contains definable
> quantities then your definition is vague and ambiguous.

Fast enough so that my client is willing to keep paying me.* They decide
how fast that is based -- one hopes -- on their ROI analysis, which they
quantify.

Enough value so that my client is willing to keep paying me.....

>Who determines the
> business value?

The client. Always.

> Do you go out and get ROI numbers on the projects you do for your customers?

Actually yes. I just asked a client to estimate cost savings based on
software of mine that they used. They quantified it for me.

> Or is business
> value a feel good thing that you and your customer agree on at the end of
> the project?

The client defines business value continuously throughout the project.

Take care.

-----
* I might factor in how much future business I can expect from
referrals, but let us keep the model simple for now.

--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
